Abstract 16
The functional properties of soluble nano-sized soy protein aggregates produced by pH treatment 17 followed by ultrasonication (US) were investigated. Commercial soy protein isolate (SPI) was 18 subjected to pH treatment under acidic (pH 2-4) or alkaline (pH 9-12) conditions followed by US 19 before neutralizing to pH 7. The pH treatment at pH 12 followed by sonication for 5 min (pH12 20 + US5) was the most effective in reducing the sizes and turbidity of soluble protein aggregates, 21 enhancing protein solubility and surface hydrophobicity, and modifying protein subunits. The 22 pH12 + US5 treated SPI increased protein solubility from 1.49% for the control to 82.73%, 23 producing soluble protein aggregates with average size of 22 nm. SPI nanoemulsions prepared 24 using pH12 + US5 treated protein and canola oil had particle sizes in the range of 70 to 117 nm. 25 Nanoemulsions and nanocomplexes (no oil) prepared with the SPI nano-aggregates provided 26 good protection of vitamin D3 against UV exposure (180 min), with retention of 73.5 and 70.7 %, 27 respectively, compared to 5.2% in the control. This new treatment may offer an effective method 28 to modify the functional properties of commercial SPI for use as building blocks for preparing 29 nanoparticles and nano-structures to protect and deliver bioactive compounds. 30
Keywords: Soy protein, pH treatment, ultrasound, encapsulation, nanoparticles, vitamin D3 31

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 33
sections.text:
Soy proteins are of high nutritional quality compared with other plant proteins. They provide a 34 relatively well-balanced supply of essential amino acids including lysine (Boye, et al., 2010). 35 Soy protein products contain high concentrations of isoflavones, especially genistein, which 36 were reported to alleviate the symptoms of menopause and linked to relatively low rates of breast 37 cancer in East Asia (Smil, 2000). Soy protein isolate (SPI), produced using isoelectric 38 precipitation of storage proteins, is the most highly refined soy protein product containing >90% 39 protein. SPI is mostly composed of two globular protein fractions called 7S (β-conglycinin) and 40 11S (glycinin). 11S has a hexameric structure with a molecular weight of 320-360 kDa and an 41 isoelectric point of 4.6, whereas 7S has a structure similar to canavalin and phaseolin with a 42 molecular weight of 140-180 kDa and an isoelectric point of 4.9 (Nielsen, 1985; Riblett, Herald, 43 Schmidt, & Tilley, 2001). Soluble soy proteins can readily adsorb to oil–water interfaces where 44 they self-aggregate through intermolecular interactions, forming elastic films (walls) around oil 45 droplets (Keerati-u-rai & Corredig, 2009). Most importantly, vegetable proteins have excellent 46 biosafety, good for applications in the food and pharmaceutical industries. Many less processed 47 soy protein products, however, are generally recognized to have lower solubility and less 48 efficient emulsifying capacity compared to dairy proteins, such as casein and whey proteins 49 (Santiago, Gonzalez, Remondetto, & Bonaldo, 1998; Palazolo, Sorgentini, & Wagner, 2005). 50 The relative low solubility of soy proteins may be caused by the complexity of the tertiary and 51 quaternary structures of the 7S and 11S, close packed globular compact conformation, low 52 molecular flexibility, and high molecular sizes (Kinsella, 1979; Kim, 1985; Damodaran, 1994; 53 Wagner & Gueguen, 1995). Improvement of solubility and hence emulsifying properties of SPI 54

4
will facilitate its use as a functional and nutritional ingredient in food and pharmaceutical 55 applications. 56
High-intensity ultrasound (power ultrasound) is an effective technology for modifying structural 57 and functional properties of proteins (Chen, Chen, Ren, & Zhao, 2011). It has also been used as a 58 high-energy method to produce nanoemulsions, especially for those using proteins (McClements 59 & Rao, 2011) or polysaccharides (Camino & Pilosof, 2011) as emulsifiers. The mode of action of 60 power ultrasound treatment is attributed to cavitation, which refers to the generation and quick 61 implosion of tiny bubbles in a liquid when longitudinal sound waves pass through it. Ultrasound 62 has been tested for modifying the functional properties of commercial food proteins such as 63 whey protein concentrate, soy protein isolate, and egg white protein (Arzeni et al., 2012). 64 Ultrasonication was reported to reduce particle size and increase surface hydrophobicity of food 65 proteins (Weiss, et al., 2011). pH shifting is a chemical treatment in which protein samples are 66 exposed to an extreme alkaline or acidic pH to unfold the proteins, followed by readjustment of 67 the pH to neutrality to refold the proteins (Liang & Kristinsson, 2007). Soy protein treated by 68 this method exhibited a significant improvement of emulsifying activity and emulsion stability 69 (Jiang, Chen, & Xiong, 2009). Currently, there is little evidence on the use of pH treatment as a 70 means to produce micro- or nano-emulsions. Although pH treatment and ultrasonication have 71 been evaluated separately to improve properties of insoluble soy protein, their combined 72 treatment to improve its solubility and functional properties for the production of nanoparticles 73 and nanoemulsions has not been reported. In this study, the pH and ultrasonication combined 74 treatment was performed to produce nano-sized soy protein aggregates. The functional properties 75 of the soluble nano-sized soy protein aggregates produced by this method were evaluated. 76

The Pro-Fam 974 and Pro-Fam 84 955 are water washed intact protein (without hydrolysis with proteases). The difference between 85 the two is the pH level; the Pro-Fam 974 is at 7.0-7.5 and the later 5.0-5.5. The two soy protein 86 concentrates are traditional alcohol washed at different pH values. Insoluble SPI or 91 SPC (3 g) was added to 100 mL DI water in a 250 mL beaker and stirred with a magnetic stirrer 92 for 30 min at room temperature. The probe was placed in the beaker with a distance of 13 mm 93 from the tip of the probe to the beaker’s bottom for all the treatments. 3. Results and discussion 205 3.1 Protein solubility 206 Table 1 shows the recovery of soluble protein (%) from SPI (Pro-Fam® 955) treated with pH, 207 ultrasound, and their combinations. The control here in distilled water was a slurry with a low 208 solubility (1.49%) and high turbidity. A phase separation was observed in the control a few 209 minutes after the SPI was added to water, a phenomenon also reported by Song et al. (Song et al., 210 2013). After pH 12 treatment, the samples were exposed to sonication for 1-5 min (Table 1). 211 Compared to the treatment at pH 12 (sonication time 0 min), sonication for over than 2 minutes 212

significantly increased recovery of soluble protein (P < 0.05). The highest protein solubility 213 (82.73%) was achieved with the pH 12 + US5 treatment. Based on these results, the treatment 214 conditions that yielded higher protein solubility, i.e. pH 12 and pH 12 + US5 were selected to 215 treat other soy protein products including SPIs and SPCs (Table 2). The solubility in all protein 216 samples was significantly increased by pH 12 and further enhanced by the application of 217 ultrasound (pH 12 + US5). 218 The soluble protein recoveries of SPI (Pro-Fam® 955) treated at different pH levels plus 219 US5 are shown in Figure 1. The pH treatment at low pH values slightly increased the solubility 220 to 5.12% (pH 2.5), with no significant difference from the control. Samples receiving alkaline 221 pH treatment exhibited significantly (P < 0.05) increased protein solubility as pH increased, 222 reaching 66.54% for the pH 12 sample. When ultrasound was introduced, the recovery of soluble 223 protein was significantly enhanced, reaching 73.30% at pH 2. Further increases in soluble protein 224 recovery were observed in the alkaline + US5 treatments, where the highest recovery of 82.73% 225 was achieved at pH 12. 226 In a pH 12 + US5 test, 2M NaOH was added to protein solution to adjust pH value to 12 227 followed by sonication before it was neutralized back to pH 7 by adding 2M HCl. The addition 228 of NaOH and HCl increased the ionic strength of the solution by 0.02 M. The effect of ionic 229 strength in pH-shifting samples on protein solubility was examined by adding 0.02 and 0.1 M 230 NaCl in protein solution and sonicated for 5 min, as shown in Table 1. Compared to the pH 12 + 231 US5 treatment having a solubility of 82.73%, the 0.02 M + US5 sample had a significantly lower 232 solubility of 71.3%, which was however the contribution of ionic strength as the US5 alone 233 treatment had a solubility of 3.80% (Table 1). 234

The pH treatment was used as the first step in this study to improve the solubility of soy 235 proteins. For the Pro-Fam® 955 samples, the solubility was low (1.49%) before the pH 236 treatments. After unfolding at low or high pH values and refolding at pH 7, all the protein 237 samples exhibited improved solubility (Figure 1). Especially, the Pro-Fam® 955 samples unfold 238 at pH 12 had the most drastic increase in protein solubility, 42 times higher than that of the 239 control. Jiang et al. (2010) reported that between the 7S and 11S globulins in soy proteins, pH 240 treatment had much less effect on the solubility of 7S. They thus attributed the enhancement in 241 soy protein solubility to 11S, and postulated that the pH12 alkaline treatment permanently 242 disrupted hydrophobic and van der Walls interactions in 11S. The SH and S-S data reported in 243 Table 1 exhibited an increase in free sulfhydryl and double bonds (S-S) when the samples were 244 treated with pH shifting and ultrasound. These treatments also had a high protein solubility 245 showing that the increase in double bonds contributed to increase solubility. Jiang, Chen, & 246 Xiong (2009) also reported that the extensive soy protein structure unfolding by pH 12 treatment 247 was accompanied by cleavage of some disulfide bonds between subunits in glycinin. These 248 proposed structural changes and enhanced intra-molecular repulsion interactions in SPI after pH 249 treatment would contribute to the improved soluble protein recovery reported in Tables 1-2. 250 The application of ultrasound after pH treatment resulted in further increase in soy protein 251 solubility in all the treatments (Figure 1). A number of recent studies have also documented a 252 significant increase in solubility of SPI after ultrasound treatment (Arzeni et al., 2012; Tang, 253 Wang, Yang, & Li, 2009; Chen et al., 2012; Hu et al., 2013). Most previous studies with SPI 254 samples involved an extended sonication time (10 to 30 min) without a chemical treatment, 255 achieving protein aggregate sizes of 250 nm to 8.5 µm, significantly larger than those reported in 256
this work (22 to 313 nm). Nevertheless, they reported a higher SPI solubility compared to the 257

solubility of 3.80% in the 5-min ultrasound alone treatment in this study (Table 1). Besides the 258 differences in the protein samples used, it may also be caused by the longer sonication time, 259 higher total energy input (kJ/mL), and stronger localized cavitation activities due to small probe 260 sizes used in their studies. The mode of action of an ultrasound treatment in a liquid, also known 261 as sonication, is often attributed to acoustic cavitation activities (Kentish & Feng, 2014). The 262 physical forces produced by cavitation, such as shear forces, shock waves, and impingement due 263 to water jet at a solid and liquid interface may alter the structures of protein macromolecules 264 leading to increased protein solubility. Intense cavitation can cause breakage of soy protein 265 aggregates, and reduction in particle sizes (Arzeni et al., 2012). Sonication can also break the 266 non-covalent and covalent bonds, causing SPI solubility increase (Hu et al., 2003). This could be 267 especially true for the strong alkali (pH 12) and ultrasound combined treatment used in this work. 268 The turbidity and SDS-PAGE data reported in the following sections also support the presence of 269 disrupted non-covalent and covalent bonds in the pH 12 + US5 treatment. 270 271 3.2 Surface hydrophobicity 272 For samples subjected to acidic pH treatments, the surface hydrophobicity (H0) values decreased 273 as pH levels increased and were slightly lower than that of the control (Figure 1). The H0 values 274 of samples treated under alkaline conditions were significantly (P < 0.05) higher than those 275 treated under acidic conditions. The SPI proteins unfolded under more basic conditions had 276 higher H0 values, reaching 212 at pH 12. Addition of ultrasound to the samples treated by a pH 277 treatment resulted in a significant increase (P < 0.05) in H0 values in all the treatments, compared 278 to the pH alone treatments. 279

Protein surface hydrophobicity is determined by the number of hydrophobic groups on 280 the protein surface that is in contact with the polar aqueous environment. Therefore, the observed 281 increase in H0 in samples may be caused by the new surfaces created by ultrasonic breakdown of 282 large protein aggregates as well as relocation of some originally embedded hydrophobic groups 283 to soluble protein surfaces. The relocation is caused by protein unfolding and re-folding during a 284 pH treatment (Jiang, Chen, & Xiong, 2009) or by the physical forces produced by acoustic 285 cavitation in a sonication treatment (Chen et al., 2012; Hu et al., 2013; Hu et al., 2003). 286 Noticeably, acidic treatments did not increase the H0 (Figure 1), an observation in agreement 287 with the report of Jiang et al. (Jiang, Chen, & Xiong, 2009). It is possible that the unfolding and 288 re-folding process in acidic treatments does not move the hydrophobic groups in SPI. 289 It can be seen from Figure 1 that protein samples with higher surface hydrophobicity (H0) 290 also had high solubility, an observation in agreement with the reports of Hu et al. (2013) and 291 Wagner et al. (2010). Hu et al. (2013) postulated the higher solubility of alkaline treated soy 292 protein with increased surface hydrophobicity (Ho) might be an indication of decreased 293 intermolecular interactions between the hydrophobic groups on the surface of protein. Wagner et 294 al (2010) held that “solubility is not exclusively determined by the degree of exposure of 295 hydrophobic zones.” In this work, the smaller sizes of the soluble protein aggregates in the 296 treated protein solution may also contribute to the increased solubility even when the H0 values 297 were relatively high. 298 299 3.3 SDS-PAGE of soluble SPI 300 SDS-PAGE of the soluble fraction of SPI samples was conducted under both reducing and non-301 reducing conditions. The application of ultrasound at a power input of 0.7 W/mL to pH-shifted SPI 326 significantly altered the electrophoretic pattern in both the acidic and base treatment samples. 327 This is evidenced by breakdown of high molecular weight aggregates at the top of the stacking 328 gel and concomitant emergence of basic polypeptides bands of 11S and increase in intensity of 329 7S subunits (α’, α) (Figures 2(b)-2 & 3(b)-2), which can be attributed to cleavage of 330
intermolecular disulfide bonds. It appears that the unfolding and re-folding process in a pH 331 process makes SPI more susceptible to sonication treatment. The functional changes that occur in 332 proteins upon ultrasonication are usually attributed to the mechanical effects of acoustic 333 cavitation that causes structural changes in proteins (Weiss, et al., 2011). The acidic and basic 334 subunits produced or enhanced by sonication are responsible for the noted increases in solubility 335 in both the acidic and alkaline pH + US samples. In Figures 2 and 3, it can be seen that the total 336 staining intensity across the different lanes is different. Since the soluble protein concentration in 337 each treatment sample was different, to reach the same amount of protein (0.05 mg) in the 338 mixture loaded to the SDS-PAGE panes, the protein concentration in each buffer was different. 339 Also, the amount of buffer added in the mixture was different which may cause a difference in 340 the intensity of staining. 341 342 3.4 Particle size and turbidity 343 The pH treatment and sonication were used in this study to modify the functional properties of 344 soy protein. This is partially manifested by a significant increase in protein solubility (Tables 1-2) 345 and reduction in the sizes of soluble protein aggregates (Figures 4 and 5). For the control, the 346 D[4,3] of the protein aggregates and Abs600 of the solution was 376.1 nm and 0.10, respectively. 347 Regardless of pH, the D[4,3] of the soluble SPI from the acidic pH + US treatment were 348

However, solutions of soy protein from acidic pH + US treatments were 350 more turbid than that of the pH treatment alone samples (Figure 4B). The interplay between 351 particle size and turbidity for the treatments with alkaline treatment with and without sonication 352 was markedly different from that of the acidic counterparts. Alkaline treatment with and without 353 ultrasound treatments recorded a significant reduction in D[4,3] when pH was increased (Figure 354 5A), with the smallest D[4,3] of 21.8 nm for the pH 12 + US treated protein samples. The Abs600 355 of the two treatments, however, behaved in a different way. The Abs600 of alkaline + US treated 356 SPI was high at pH 9 (0.57) followed by a rapid decrease, whereas the Abs600 of alkaline pH 357 alone treatment remained low at pH 9 and 10 and then experienced a quick increase at pH 12 358 (Figure 5B). 359 High intensity ultrasound treatment is a well-established method for particle size 360 reduction in dispersions and emulsions (Hielscher, 2005). When used in protein dispersions, 361 sonication was reported to significantly reduce the particle sizes of SPI (Arzeni et al., 2012; Hu 362 et al., 2003), SPC (Jambrak et al., 2009), and defatted soy flake slurry (Karki et al., 2010), 363 normally with a relatively long treatment time. The ultrasonic breakdown of particles or 364 aggregates in dispersions is often attributed to the physical forces produced by cavitation, such as 365 shear forces produced by micro-streaming and normal impingement from the water jets at solid-366 liquid interfaces. How an ultrasound treatment reduces the particle sizes of a product will be 367 determined by total energy input and accumulative effect of cavitation, as determined by the 368 APD, treatment time, properties of the food matrix, and temperature. In this study, sonication 369 was applied after unfolding of globular soy proteins with high or low pH treatments, which 370 opened up its tightly packed structure making it more susceptible to breakdown by external 371

forces. Consequently, the alkaline pH + US treatments resulted in a rapid reduction in particle 372 sizes, and increasing pH produced smaller particle sizes. The latter may be caused by a more 373 extended protein conformation induced under more basic conditions as postulated by Jiang et al. 374 (Jiang, Chen, & Xiong, 2009) with larger surface areas to interact with ultrasonic waves to 375 produce smaller D[4,3] values. 376 Turbidity (cloudiness) of dispersion is proportional to both the number concentration (N) 377 and sizes of the particles (Gregory, 1998). The number concentration (N) is determined by the 378 number of particles in the dispersion. Therefore, the turbidity of a SPI solution is determined by 379 both the number of soluble soy protein aggregates in the solution measured by solubility and the 380 sizes of the soluble protein aggregates. Among acidic pH treated samples, the amount of protein 381 solubilized in the solution was low (Figure 1) and particle sizes were relatively large (Figure 4A), 382 resulting in low turbidity values (Figure 4B). The acidic pH + US samples had significantly 383 higher turbidity (Figure 4B), which was mainly attributed to an over 10-fold increase in 384 solubility compared to pH alone treatments (Figure 1), although its particle sizes were smaller 385 compared to the pH alone samples (Figure 4A). A rapid decrease in turbidity was observed at pH 386 4 for pH and ultrasound treated samples. At pH 4, nearing isoelectric point, the SPI dissolved in 387 dispersion decreased from 37.74 mg/mL at pH 3.5 to 9.24 mg/mL (Figure 1), and this 388 significantly lower amount of protein in the sample directly contributed to the low turbidity value. 389 Similarly, the monotonic decrease in the turbidity of alkaline + US samples (Figure 5B) can be 390 related to reduction in particle sizes (Figure 5A) because the solubility remained high for all 391 alkaline + US samples (Figure 1). A “jump” of turbidity can be observed in pH 12 samples from 392 0.14 at pH 11 to 0.55 (Figure 5B), which should be caused by the significant increase in protein 393

solubility from 16.32 mg/mL at pH 11 to 66.54 mg/mL at pH 12 (Figure 1). The appearance of 394 SPI treated by pH alone and in combination with sonication is shown in Figure 6. 395 396 3.5 Nanoemulsion and photostability of vitamin D3 against UV exposure 397 Small emulsion droplet sizes, approximately 70 nm, were observed in nanoemulsions made with 398 soluble proteins (Pro-Fam® 955, Pro-Fam® 974, and Acron SM) by the pH 12 + US5 treatment 399 as compared to other nanoemulsions (Figure 7). Compared to the pH alone treatment, the 400 combination of pH and ultrasound in all soy protein samples resulted in significantly smaller 401 particle sizes. The pH 12 + US5 treated SPI (Pro-Fam® 955) had the smallest particle sizes 402 (Figure 5A) and better solubility (Table 1). Protein solubility has been reported as the most 403 practical index of protein functional properties, and improved solubility would enhance protein 404 functionalities, including emulsifying capacity (Arzeni et al., 2012; Tang, Wang, Yang, & Li, 405 2009; Chen et al., 2012; Hu et al., 2003). In this study, the nanoemulsions made from soy 406 proteins with higher solubility by the pH 12 + US5 had smaller particle sizes, and may have a 407 better emulsifying capacity compared other samples (Figure 7). 408 409 Photostability of vitamin D3 in distilled water, in SPI nanocomplex, and in SPI nanoemulsion 410 against UV radiation was further investigated. Upon UV exposure, the control sample (vitamin 411 D3 in untreated soy protein) experienced rapid degradation, with a remaining vitamin D3 412 concentration of 5.2% after 180 minutes (Figure 8). In contrast, the nanocomplexes and 413 nanoemulsions exhibited protective effects for vitamin D3 against UV exposure with 414 significantly lower degradation rates. After 180 minutes of UV exposure, 70.7 and 73.5% of 415 vitamin D3 was retained in nanocomplexes and nanoemulsions, respectively. Previous studies 416

have utilized different protective structures to protect vitamin D, such as using casein micelles 417 (Semo, Kesselman, Danino, & Livney, 2007), β-lactoglobulin and a β-lactoglobulin-pectin 418 complex (Ron, Zimet, Bargarum, & Livney, 2010), and zein nanoparticles coated with 419 carboxymethyl chitosan (Luo, Teng, & Wang, 2012), with varying degrees of success. 420 Photooxidation of vitamin D3 was reported to be an ene-type reaction with singlet oxygen in 421 addition to the 1,4-cycloaddition reaction initiated by light absorption by sensitizers (Yamada et 422 al., 1983; Li & Min, 1998). Therefore, any measures that reduce UV light absorption by 423 nanoparticles, and thus reach vitamin D3, will help to retard the degradation reactions. In this 424 case, UV light needs to penetrate through the soy protein emulsifying walls before it reaches 425 vitamin D3. It is possible that the nanocomplex did not provide sufficient wall structure to 426 enhance vitamin D3 protection, and thus, resulted in lower stability when compared to the 427 nanoemulsion. The light-scattering property of the nanoparticles was reported to contribute to a 428 reduction in UV light intensity on the nanoparticles (Carlotti et al., 2005). In addition, the 429 aromatic hydroxyl groups and double bonds in soy protein may absorb UV light, thus reducing 430 the UV light intensity reaching vitamin D3 encapsulated in the nanoparticles or associated with 431 the nanocomplex (Luo, Teng, & Wang, 2012). 432 433 4. Conclusions 434 This study shows that the sequential pH treatment and ultrasonication significantly increased 435 solubility of commercial soy protein isolates and concentrates, reduced the sizes of protein 436 aggregates to less than 100 nanometers, and resulted in improved functional properties. Soluble, 437 nanosized protein aggregates demonstrated an excellent capacity to disperse, encapsulate, and 438 protect vitamin D3. This indicates that the nano-scale soluble soy protein aggregates can be a 439
